output_examples.output: Complete TypeScript project with: (1) Project structure with src/, dist/, proper tsconfig.json (2) Tools for repos, issues, PRs with Zod validation (3) Shared API client with auth and error handling (4) Pagination and response formatting (5) Quality checklist validation (6) Build scripts and testing setup

best_practices: Use TypeScript with MCP SDK for broad compatibility and static typing
Prioritize comprehensive API coverage over limited workflow tools
Include service prefix in tool names to avoid conflicts (e.g., 'github_create_issue')
Support both JSON and Markdown response formats for flexibility
Implement pagination with limit, offset, has_more, and next_offset
Provide actionable error messages that guide agents toward solutions
Extract common functionality into reusable helper functions
Use Zod (TypeScript) or Pydantic (Python) for runtime input validation
Set proper tool annotations (readOnlyHint, destructiveHint, etc.)
Create comprehensive evaluations with 10+ realistic, complex questions
Test with MCP Inspector before deployment
Use streamable HTTP for remote servers, stdio for local tools
anti_patterns: Creating too many narrow workflow tools instead of flexible building blocks
Generic tool names without service context (e.g., 'send_message' instead of 'slack_send_message')
Returning entire datasets without pagination support
Vague error messages that don't guide the agent toward solutions
Copy-pasting similar code instead of extracting shared utilities
Missing input validation or relying on manual validation instead of schemas
Incomplete tool descriptions without explicit input/output schemas
Evaluation questions that depend on current state or have unstable answers
Using synchronous I/O operations instead of async/await
Skipping the quality checklist before considering implementation complete

faq.question: Should I use TypeScript or Python for my MCP server?
faq.answer: TypeScript is recommended for most cases due to high-quality SDK support, broad compatibility in execution environments like MCPB, and excellent AI model generation quality. Python with FastMCP is a good alternative for Python-heavy ecosystems or when you prefer Python's syntax.

faq.question: Should I build comprehensive API coverage or specialized workflow tools?
faq.answer: Prioritize comprehensive API coverage. This gives agents flexibility to compose operations. While workflow tools can be convenient, some clients support code execution that can combine basic tools effectively. When uncertain, comprehensive coverage is the safer choice.

faq.question: What transport should I use for my MCP server?
faq.answer: Use streamable HTTP with stateless JSON for remote servers (easier to scale and maintain). Use stdio for local integrations and command-line tools. Avoid SSE as it's deprecated in favor of streamable HTTP.

faq.question: How do I test my MCP server effectively?
faq.answer: Use the MCP Inspector for manual testing during development. Create comprehensive evaluations with 10+ realistic questions that require multiple tool calls and test real-world workflows. Run evaluations using the provided scripts with Claude to measure effectiveness.

faq.question: What makes a good evaluation question?
faq.answer: Good questions are: independent (not dependent on other questions), read-only (non-destructive), complex (requiring multiple tool calls), realistic (based on real use cases), verifiable (single clear answer), and stable (answer won't change over time). They should test deep exploration, not simple keyword searches.

faq.question: How do I handle pagination in my tools?
faq.answer: Always respect the limit parameter, implement offset or cursor-based pagination, return metadata (has_more, next_offset, total_count), and never load all results into memory. Default to 20-50 items per page.

permissions: Network access to external APIs being integrated
File system access for stdio transport
Environment variables for API keys and configuration
